title: What is an RL environment? w/ Nous Research's Roger Jin

rawLines.text: Hey guys. Uh so I'm Roger from News
Research. We train open source language
models. Um today we're going to be
talking about uh some of our RL
infrastructure.
Um so I'll first give a motivation for
like reinforcement learning in general
or like how how I like to think about
reinforcement learning. Um and I'll talk
about a little bit about like the RL
infrastructure news. Um and specifically
I'll focus on um our environment
abstraction. Um so start with like
supervised learning. Um yeah you know is
you guys kind of like know the deal. You
have some model you have some data set
some loss function. Um and you want to
like take some steps on your model. You
want to make small updates to your model
to to optimize that loss. So it kind of
like looks like this right? um like you
have some like kind of like nice loss
function, well behaved like smooth,
continuous um and um and like a step of
training in supervised learning kind of
looks like you take this like um like
this ball um and you like you press play
on this picture and you kind of like
pause it and the ball moves over like a
little bit and then that's like one step
to training.
Um but like does this work for like any
arbitrary like loss function you can
write down. Um and the answer is like no
like consider accuracy, right? It takes
on n plus one like discrete values if
you have like data set of size n like 0
over n to like dot dot like um n / n,
right? Um what would like the same plot
look like if we use like accuracy
instead? I guess like error rate or
something um if you want to make it like
a decision problem. Um so that that's
going to look like a piece constant
function of like any any weight that you
pick from your model. Um right so um the
ball doesn't like doesn't roll anymore.
Um and uh so that that's like this is
like one limitation of supervised
learning. Um like and um like where does
this like sort of show up? Well like if
you're doing language modeling um every
time you're picking a token like um you
can't back prop through that picking
operation anymore because like um the
next token would be like kind of like a
um the index of the chosen token is like
a peacewise constant function like
anyway. So um you introduce like that
this piewise constant node into your
compute graph at that point. Um and then
like that means you can't really back
prop through like multiple um picking
operations for for these tokens. Um so
what that means is like under like
greedy sampling supervised learning
can't really help you with objectives on
multiple tokens. If you're if you're
interested in like rewarding a language
model for like how funny like a joke is
or something you can't like directly
approach that with supervised
learning. Um okay. Okay, so these are
some limitations of supervised learning.
It only works with like nice loss
functions, right? U doesn't play well
with objectives over like multi-step
trajectories that don't decompose well
into like these singlestep objectives.
Um and um the main medium that the
modeler has to communicate with the
model is data. So we need like expert
samples of what is good. Um and there's
like a kind of deficit which is like
there's no way to demonstrate what is
bad in supervised learning. You kind of
just you have to tell the model very
well like what is good. Um and uh there
there are like kind of surprising
results like uh like weak to strong
generalization but like in general like
the model outperforming the expert
labelers would be like kind of very
surprising. Okay. So moving on to RL. Um
in RL we have this like different setup
where we have this like agent in an
environment and it can take actions and
influence the environment um and then uh
get rewards and um the rewards can sort
of like be anything. very like up to us
and um they they're usually kind of like
weird looking behave functions like they
can be discreet they can be like points
in a game they can be like the accuracy
um so um and um that that's really fine
in RL and normal and the goal is to
learn this like policy which controls
this agent to to maximize the sum of
like discounted rewards over time
um so like going back to a language
modeling world like um how does this how
does like RL directly map onto language
modeling or language modeling map onto
RL. So the states are like the text
prefixes. So the initial states like the
prompt. Um the actions are the next
tokens. Um that means like a language
model is like exactly what a policy is,
right? A policy maps a state to a
probably distribution of next actions. A
language model maps a text prefix to a
probability distribution of next tokens.
Um so all we have to do really is like
specify our favorite reward function
like how funny like our joke is,
whatever. Um and then we can optimize
our model against this with like all the
fancy algorithms from RL.
Um, so this is just like some write up
of like the RL objective. Um, and it
kind of shows like um the like the trick
here is like there's this expectation,
right? You're taking an expectation over
the policy. Um, and so the thing on the
inside that that thing might be like
discreet that's like reward like you
might have some like accuracy thing as
your reward, but we're kind of like um
we kind of like describe the reward
using this like highle language of like
how humans might assign rewards. But
then we're kind of like compiling this
back into like a differentiable loss
function with this expectation thing of
like smoothing out smoothing out. So
that's like kind of the trick here. So
in that sense like rewards are sort of
this like abstraction like we end up
with a smooth like differentiable loss
at the end. Um but like we have this
like language of rewards to communicate
intent to the
model. Um yeah um and like you can like
do some math to like optimize the model.
Um
pause. Okay. So um uh the like you know
the the map that's the algorithm that's
implied by like policy gradient is is
sort of like reinforced um where you can
like take rollouts um you can take
samples from your model um and um and uh
kind of like estimate this uh this
gradient in uh policy gradient with the
with the mean of these uh the reward
returns from the the rollouts. Um and um
this is like a you know quite a simple
algorithm if if you kind of like look at
if you kind of stare at like this part.
Um it sort of looks like just like
weighted supervised fine-tuning right
like you have this like log of like the
the probability of a token and like some
like weight on it. Um and reinforce this
is like the return but it doesn't have
to be that like you can replace it with
like some advantage. Um like GRPO does
that right? It's like the reward norm uh
the the the uh the mean uh like the the
normalized rewards. Um and
uh and uh this like uh this is kind of
like nice, right? Uh so in RL like we
can work with like nearly arbitrary
rewards. So discrete, non-ifferiable,
whatever. Um you can have objectives
over these like multi-step trajectories.
uh you can communicate intent to the
model like in this like additional way
and you can also demonstrate like what
is bad in addition to like what is good
simply through like negative rewards. Um
the model outperforming expert labelers
is is possible the model learning like
self-correction is like expected. Um and
um yeah we've seen like kind of cool
emergent behaviors of like the like 01
03 R1 kind of like kind of these like
thinking models that kind of learn their
own approach to to solving
problems. Okay. Um so we we're now like
kind of moving into this era of
experience. So like since you know 2020
or so like maybe even before that we've
been scaling up data um pre-training
data SFT. Um the goal being to get to to
get this like very diverse large pool of
uh of of good inputs high quality inputs
to train our model. Um and now like we
were kind of motivated to do the same
thing for RL environments. And
um like previously I guess like the
format of the data wasn't so important
because like there was there were these
like you know share GPT or open AAI
format whatever but and it was kind of
annoying that there was like multiple
formats but it was kind of easy to
interconvert between them. Um but these
environments are sort of like written in
code and it's like much harder to kind
of like share these environments. So,
um, in open source, we kind of like want
to build up our collection of like just
like how we built up this like huge pool
of like data, we want to build up this
like huge pool of environments. Um, and
so like there just needs to be some kind
of like standard for open source
developers to um to all like work
together to like build up this, you
know, to scale environments up to like
millions and millions of environments.
Um, so like so we want to pose a
question here like what is the
abstraction that will allow open source
to scale up to a million environments?
What would that look like?
Um okay so um I guess like first like we
can think about like where where do the
environments like live in the larger
picture of like some training
infrastructure. Um so in news we have
this like distributed training like
infrastructure. It's it's pretty
standard. Um we've got these like three
microservices. So the trainer is one
microser handles like back prop. Um
inference um is another microser right?
It's like an open AI API um that that
serves the model um the current policy.
Um and we also have this like
environment manager like rollout service
which which handles all the
environments. Um and each of these
environments if you have like multiple
of them is it's also its like own
microser. So um that means that each
environment can have its own like kind
of code execution environment or like
like Python environment or like it can
run on its own hardware. If for some
reason you want to like run an
environment like on your phone or
something like you could you could just
do that. Um, and these these
environments run like async from the
trainer, right? So, um, so they don't
like really care about the trainer.
They're just like their goal is just
like constantly produce robots,
constantly produce like data in
Ever um, if you wanted to like resurrect
some kind of ancient environment from
like 2019. Um, like yeah, you you can
just like make like a Docker container
or something and um, and you can you can
run like this like ancient
environment. Okay. And um the the
environment interface like I guess the
minimal environment interface that that
we try we kind of expose is rather
simple. So just like these like two
things there's like a lot of other stuff
that you can do like you know like
logging and whatever. Um but like at a
minimum like these two things. So get
item and collect trajectories. So get
item is like kind of like you know just
a data loader kind of like a function.
Um so you can get like a row from your
data set or if you like are working with
like larger batches you can kind of get
a batch from your data set. Um if if you
have like some fancy curriculum you want
to do um get item kind of can manage
that curriculum for you. Uh and then
collect trajectories takes in any kind
of item that's returned by get item and
then maps it to a group of uh scored
rollouts. Um so uh I I guess it's kind
of like
uh good that we
uh uh or okay so I'll try to like
motivate why we why we have this like
collect trajectories function. Um so
like I guess another like common kind of
abstraction is like that we split up the
rollout part from the scoring part or
the inference part from the scoring
part. But collect trajectories is is a
fusion of both of these. It handles both
inference and scoring. And we
deliberately chose that because like
what happens when you try to like do
like multi-turn or like like multi- aent
um with like a separate scorer function
um then then things kind of get like
weird. Um so we have this like fused um
inference and scoring function collect
trajectories where we're we're kind of
agnostic to how many like in how many
times like inference and scoring happen.
Um so u multi-step multi- aent are kind
of like automatically supported by by
this
method. Okay. And um the atomic unit of
training data that's produced by this
function is a is a group. Um so this
kind of encapsulates like what the data
preparation would look like for like DPO
grpo um SFT with like you know group
size one. Um, it also allows you to
customize like what a group even means,
right? So, gRPO is like has a setup
where like a group is like um you have
like multiple rollouts for the same
problem, but it doesn't like kind of
have to be that way. Um, if you wanted
to like for example sample a batch of
like similar problems, for example, I
have this example here of like same like
chess position, but it's just like black
to move in one and white to move in the
other. Um, on the left it's like uh mate
and one for black, on the right it's
like mate and 18 for white, right? So,
um, so if you want to like group like
similar problems together instead of
like having the same problem and like
doing multiple rollouts, like you can
totally do that with with this. We we
don't lock you into like the GRPO
official like definition of what a group
is. Um, another like kind of weird
quirky thing about uh our design is that
uh at least for text, the thing that's
returned by each of these environments
is like the literal tokens. So it's not
like it's not text, it's not like
messages, it's it's the tokens. Um, and
um, this allows you to deal with like
weird little quirks about like
inference. Like for example, like maybe
your your inference API um, gives you
like an EOS token even if like your uh,
your max context length was is like
executed. So it inserts this like kind
of fake EOS, the model didn't want to
stop, but it was like forced to stop.
Um, so you kind of like want to strip
that out when you're training on it so
it model doesn't like stop in the middle
of it like generation.
Um say say you wanted to like make a uh
like a waifu group chat environment or
something, right? So um and um you have
like the the roles being like the
usernames or something, right? Um and
that that requires a custom chat
template. Um and that's that's totally
fine. We can support a per environment
chat template in in this framework. Um
another thing you can do like with in in
like the token world is like the trainer
is now like agnostic to like chat versus
model. Um, and what that means is like
you can you can do all like the cool
like R10 zero kind of style like
experiments. Um, but it also means that
you can mix together instruction uh
instruct and base model fine-tuning like
all at once, right? So um uh so for
example, you can do like if you we're
training this like code assistant model,
right? You can do chat code assistant
style RL um um but you can also mix that
with like base model style like autocomp
completion um RL. Um, and another thing
you can do if you have like to the
environment return tokens is you can
override the GRPO advantages. So the the
GRPO advantages are like just like kind
of token level weights on on the SFT,
right? Um, and um if you had some reason
to like um some way to like kind of get
token level rewards, for example, you
have like some stack trace from your um
from your like interpreter um and you
see like exactly which lines are are
like involved in the error. um the these
environments can then override the
advantages like competed by the trainer
and you can have like um token level
rewards or like you know weird like
token level like reweighings of the
advantages. Okay. Um and um we wanted to
make this kind of like extensible. So um
this is just an example of like some uh
kind of like extension that I thought
of. Um like suppose that you wanted
different environments to support
different like attention masking
schemes. So like if you had like super
long context for some environment, maybe
you would want to use like sliding
window attention for that one. Um if you
had some kind of like uh some kind of
like smarter way to do like sliding
window like you know if you maybe just
like if you have some like protein um
question answer environment where you
put in the protein sequence you try to
ask a question about it. Maybe you want
to only do attention um where like the
contact points of the of the tertiary
structure are. Um so like maybe you want
to do something where you like um your
your environment passes the uh inputs to
like a flex attention block mass getter
um within the this like score data group
that's
returned. So so these environments are
are kind of like extensible. You can
come up with your own like weird wacky
things that you want to like give the
trainer. Okay. Um and um so all of this
was like joint work with uh Dakota
Shannon J Chen and Technomium. And
